topic.title: How it Works - Accelerated Link Down

body.p: When a hot-removal occurs in a standard PCIe-compliant switch, the PCIe Base Specification 4.0 stipulates that the port must transition from L0 to Recovery. Since the EP is removed, the port will remain in recovery for 24mS which triggers a timeout in the recovery phase allowing for the port to be declared down.

fig.title: Typical PCIe recovery time during a hot-remove

body.p: Figure 1 illustrates a time line from a device hot-removal to the 24mS recovery time where a link is officially declared down. In this figure, the presence pin on the device is defined and indicates to the host that the device is removed. While a downstream port is in recovery, traffic continues to flow into the downed port and is buffered. By PCIe back pressuring and recovery rules, the switch must buffer and then back pressure until either the port is declared down or the port returns to L0.

section.title: Why accelerate Linkdown?
section.p: When an EP is removed and before the port is declared down, Switchtec will buffer data to the downed port until such time as the port is either declared down or recovers. In either case, once the port is declared down or returns to L0, traffic can then begin flowing to the port. In Figure 2 the EP is performing a memRd from host memory. The MemRd TLP is issued from the EP to the host and the resulting CplD is returned from the host to the EP.

fig.title: Normal MemRd from EP to Host

section.p: In the case where an EP is removed, the port LTSSM goes from L0 to Recovery. During the time from the port entering recovery to the port being declared down, all the outstanding MemRds from that EP are still queued up in the host and being processed. The host continues to send CplD to the removed EP. Since the EP is removed, but the port is not yet declared down, the switch buffers the CplDs. This is illustrated in Figure 3.

fig.title: EP is removed, but traffic is still directed to EP

section.p: Once the back pressure reaches the upstream port, the upstream port becomes head-of-line (HOL) blocked. This means the host can no longer issue CplD to the switch upstream port. This causes the upstream port in the switch to stop issuing credits to the host for CplD which ultimately blocks other drives waiting for CplDs from getting completions. Figure 4 illustrates this head-of-line blocking as a result of a downed port taking too long to declare link down. In this case, the system will be momentarily paused until the downstream port connected to the removed EP can begin discarding traffic.

fig.title: EP removed but port is not declared down leads to head-of-line block

section.p: The net effect of the head-of-line block issue is that hosts or EPs may encounter completion timeouts due to back-pressure during port recovery to Linkdown. There are two main solutions to this problem:

li.p: Increasing completion timeouts at the host and EPs to be greater than that of PCIe Base Specification worst case recovery (48mS)
Accelerating link down detection so that downstream ports where an EP is removed can declare link down sooner than the full recovery time

section.title: Switchtec-specific features for supporting accelerated link down
section.p: Switchtec features a mechanism to accelerate link down handling. There are two main mechanisms used:

li.p: Link down acceleration using link state change

section.p: Switchtec uses a combination of these two mechanisms to accelerate link down in the following configurations:

As illustrated in Figure 5, accelerated link down is triggered as a function of presence, link state change, number of times in recovery, and how long the port stays in recovery. The algorithm was built to provide the fastest link down detection mechanism while providing full support for valid transitions from L0 to recovery (such as speed change).

section.title: Link down acceleration using PRSNT#
section.p: For configuration where the Endpoint has a PRSNT# pin, the pin can be used to signal to the switch to accelerate the link down process and shortcut the recovery time. This ensures that the link is disabled well before the 24mS recovery timer has expired.

fig.title: Accelerated link down using PRSNT# as a trigger

section.p: In Figure 6, the assertion of PRSNT# has shortcut the link down process allowing for the port to come down much faster than the typical case. This allows for buffered traffic in the port to drain and prevents back pressuring of the host for a removed Endpoint.

Unfortunately, in specific connector types used in PCIe hot-plug (like U.2), the presence pin is the longest pin in the connector making it last to un-mate. This results in very long PRSNT# assertion times on device removal (in some cases > 20mS). This is illustrated in Figure 7.

fig.title: Accelerated link down using PRSNT# as trigger fails if PRSNT# is longest pin (slow remove)

section.title: Link down acceleration using link state change
section.p: In addition to link down acceleration using PRSNT#, Switchtec also employs a link down accelerator based on link state changes in the LTSSM state machine of each port. The specific state change is the transition from L0 to Recovery (also known as L2R - L0 to Recovery). The algorithm to accelerate based on link state is based on an internal timer which is triggered when the link state changes from L0 to Recovery (L2R). The timer is set for 5mS which allows for all valid transitions through recovery to occur as normal (link retrain, link width change, link speed change, etc). If the timer expires and the link state is still in recovery, the port is disabled to accelerate the link down.

fig.title: Accelerated link down using link state change as a trigger where link state change occurs first

section.p: In Figure 8, the time line shows a hot-removal followed by a state transition from L0 to recovery. This is where the 5mS timer is started and 5mS later the fast link down mechanism is activated. In this example, the "late" presence change happens after the link is brought down so there is no additional accelerated link down.

Figure 8 illustrates the behavior for the no sideband case as well with the exception that there is no PRSNT# change (because there is no PRSNT# pin) and the Presence MSI is synthesized by the Switchtec firmware.

note.p: The 5mS timer is configurable to allow tuning for different link conditions. Spec-compliant LTSSM behavior can be selected by setting this field:
1. Equal to or greater than 54ms which allows normal Recovery timeout
2. 0 to totally disable the Link down acceleration triggered by link state change

section.title: Link down acceleration when using PCIe Optical Connectors
section.p: Accelerated link down will rely purely on link state and the behavior is identical to what is described in Link down acceleration using link state change. For optical connectors (using SFF-8644/43 form factor or others), Switchtec requires the definition of PRSNT# for use as cable presence detection (used to sense the local plug and used to enable power to a powered transceiver for sideband communication).

note.p: 1The presence pin for optical is used as cable presence and not used as "device presence". Cable presence will not be used to determine out-of-band presence. Cable presence will also not be used for accelerated link down detection.
